abstract.p: Background. The use of intramedullary nail fixation for tibio-talo-calcaneal fusion is gaining popularity. There is chance of failure of procedure following faulty operative technique specially alignment. Methods. The article describes a useful application of tibial tunnel jig in inserting the calcanio-talo-tibial guide wire. Results. There is precision of few millimeters in the exit point of guide wire on talus. Conclusions. The authors believe that this helps in better positioning of nail and hence better alignment and better operative outcome.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The use of intramedullary nail fixation for tibio-talo-calcaneal fusion is gaining popularity. Many methods of fixation have been employed in the past, but intramedullary fixation has been shown to achieve higher fusion rates, provide fixation along the weight-bearing axis, and control rotational deformities.1 It is an important salvage method for patients with complex hind foot problems, including Charcot arthropathy, osteonecrosis of the talus, combined arthritis of the ankle and subtalar joint, and failed total ankle arthroplasty.2

Ankle arthrodesis is a demanding procedure, and the operation should preferably be performed by an experienced surgeon, taking into account the alignment, ligament, and muscle balance. There is chance of failure of procedure following faulty operative technique specially when there is an attempt to overcompensate malaligned ankle while ignoring correction of hind foot deformity (subtalar complex).3

Hind foot retrograde nails are load-sharing devices and they can be either straight or curved. Various studies have suggested that curved nail is far away from at-risk structures, that is, flexor hallucis longus tendon, medial plantar artery, and the lateral planter nerve as compared with straight nails.4 Hence they are relatively safer to use compared with straight nails. Lateral bent nails also provide proper hind foot alignment by maintaining 5° to 10° of valgus positioning for better gait.5

Anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) tibial tunnel jig has been mentioned in literature to be used in foot operations, including tarsometatarsal and talar fracture fixation.6 We describe its use in the accurate placement of calcanio-talo-tibial guide wire fixation for hind foot fusion, which is extremely important for correct alignment of the ankle.

sec.title: Guide Wire Placement for Hind Foot Calcanio-Talo-Tibial Nail
Technique Commonly Used
sec.p: In lateral transfibular approach, the lateral malleolus is exposed through a direct lateral incision curved distally toward the subtalar joint. The lateral malleolus is osteotomized with a bone saw obliquely at the level of the ankle joint under X-ray control. The excised lateral malleolus is preserved for later use as bone graft. Now that direct visualization of the tibiotalar and posterior talocalcaneal joint can be made, both joints are debrided of all articular cartilage down to subchondral bone. While detaching the osteotomies fibula superior peroneal retinaculum is divided. Peroneal tendons are identified just inferior to the lateral malleolus deep to superior and inferior peroneal retinaculum and preserved.

Following preparation of the bony surface a longitudinal planter incision is made anterior to the subcalcaneal fat pad slightly lateral to the midline. By doing blunt dissection entry point at the calcaneus is reached. Now a guide wire is drilled through the calcaneus, talus, and then tibia. It is either done free hand or in some orthopaedic kit where there is a drilling sleeve that helps in reaching the entry point; however, drilling is still done free hand. Position of the guide wire is confirmed by image intensifier.

sec.title: Our Technique
sec.p: We describe a useful application of tibial tunnel jig in inserting the calcanio-talo-tibial guide wire with a precision of few millimeters through the calcaneus into talus and finally into medullary cavity of tibia.

Once the joint surfaces are prepared, the ACL jig is positioned with the tip of the jig in the centre of the talus with the ankle in neutral position (Figure 1). This is done under direct vision. The guide arm of the tibial jig is oriented desirably by adjusting the guide arm with respect to the drill sleeve. There are markings on the guide arm to indicate the optimum orientation of the guide arm with respect to the drill sleeve. To determine the entry point on the calcaneus, a lateral fluoroscopic image is taken with a guide wire held adjacent to the leg. This helps us in identifying the center of the tibial canal. Now a line is drawn along the longitudinal axis of calcaneus and the point where it intersects the lateral reference line is taken as entry point of the nail. The drill sleeve is introduced through the distal slot, a longitudinal incision is made on the planter surface, and the sleeve is pushed in till it engages on the calcaneal surface with the angle of insertion approximately 90° to the surface. A guide wire is drilled through the calcaneus and talus and precisely exits through the midpoint of the talus (Figure 2). The position is checked with image intensifier. At this point, the ACL jig is removed and the guide wire is further drilled in the tibial medullary cavity.

caption.p: ACL jig is positioned with the tip of the jig in the centre of the talus.
Position of ACL jig on the calcaneus.

sec.p: As the procedure is mostly done under direct vision, it minimizes the chance of injury to structures medial to the ankle joint7 and the nail, with the help of image intensifier, is passed through the calcaneus tuberosity, hence the nail is completely surrounded by bone.
